alert.note: Alert for Bay; Dixie; Franklin; Gadsden; Gulf; Jefferson; Lafayette; Leon; Liberty; Madison; Taylor; Wakulla; Walton (Florida) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.headline: Hydrologic Outlook issued September 07 at 4:17PM EDT by NWS Tallahassee
info.description: ...MULTIPLE DAYS OF HEAVY RAINFALL EXPECTED THROUGH THIS WEEKEND... ...FLASH FLOODING POSSIBLE ON FRIDAY INTO SATURDAY... ...COASTAL RIVERINE FLOOD THREAT POTENTIALLY DEVELOPING THIS WEEKEND... .Antecedent Conditions... Over the 30 days, rainfall has been much above normal across the entire region, with some areas in the Florida Big Bend running 5-8 inches above normal. As a result, soils are fairly moist based on CREST analysis which shows much of the Florida Big Bend near 75% saturation with some pockets of 75-85% saturation in Madison County and along the Apalachicola River south of Bristol. Needless to say, North Florida is vulnerable to flash flooding. .Flood Potential and Impacts... With precipitable water values increasing Thursday and into Friday, the atmosphere will be primed to produce locally heavy rainfall. While the large scale pattern is supportive of heavy rainfall, the remaining question is exactly where the heaviest amounts will occur. Coastal areas often seem to receive the highest totals in these types of patterns, and our latest forecast features this, with 4-6 inches of rain along the coastal areas from Apalachicola eastward around Apalachee Bay. Isolated heavier totals are possible, especially if thunderstorms stall along the coastal interface. Should this occur, very heavy rainfall accumulations are possible in a short period of time, which could produce dangerous flash flooding. Slightly lower amounts are anticipated further inland to Interstate 10 and along the FL/GA border. Even so, with 2-4 inches expected in these areas, isolated heavier totals are possible, and if falling in a short period of time over already saturated soils, flash flooding could happen fairly quickly. The main impact with this system is the potential for flash flooding. The entire region is outlined in a slight risk for excessive rainfall on Friday. This is when the heaviest rain should occur across the region. However, with the moist air mass remaining in place, additional heavy rain is anticipated through the weekend, further adding to the flood threat. With multiple days of heavy rainfall, the potential for minor river flooding exists in our coastal basins. The more vulnerable basins are the Sopchoppy, St Marks, Aucilla, and Steinhatchee. Rainfall amounts of 4 to 6 inches in these basins would only produce minor riverine flooding. Higher amounts, in excess of 8 inches, would bring the potential for moderate riverine flooding. .Preparedness Actions... Should models continue to indicate an increased likelihood of a heavy rainfall, a flood watch may be issued for a portion of our area as soon as Thursday. Residents living in areas vulnerable to flash flooding should consider evaluating their flood risk and be prepared to take action to protect themselves and property from flood damage. People living near small streams and area rivers should also be alert to rapid rises in water level and be prepared to take action if warnings are issued. For more information be sure to interact with our office through twitter @NWSTALLAHASSEE.
